elements.title: Darby Jones (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that film critic Danny Peary described Darby Jones (pictured) as having been "even more typecast than the typical black actor", limited to roles in jungle-themed films?

elements.title: 666 Fifth Avenue (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the construction of 666 Fifth Avenue involved cartoon decorations, a papier-mache Santa Claus, and a 78-by-155-foot (24 by 47 m) American flag that ripped as it was being unfurled?

elements.title: Blanche Zacharie de Baralt (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Blanche Zacharie de Baralt was the University of Havana's first woman philosophy graduate and the first person to translate Tagore's poems into Spanish?

elements.title: Eifuku (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the volcano Eifuku produces bubbles of liquid carbon dioxide underwater?

elements.title: WaHu Student Apartments (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the construction of WaHu Student Apartments was delayed for one year by Minneapolis's initial rejection of a new location for the blood plasma donation center on the property?

elements.title: Neon Genesis Evangelion episode "Rei II" (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the fictional battle Operation Yashima, displayed in the Neon Genesis Evangelion episode "Rei II", inspired a real unofficial campaign in Japan to conserve electricity after the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami?

elements.title: Tongasat (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the small Pacific island nation of Tonga, represented by its satellite company Tongasat, claimed nine percent of all viable satellite orbits and became the sixth-largest holder of those orbits?

elements.title: Ralph Fisher (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Ralph Fisher bought enslaved people with brass?
